answers.author: Caleb Holder
answers.text:
I am from a city of approximately 10,800 residents; there is a University outside of city limits with approximately 7,100 students. We do not have a non-voting student member on the City Council. Personally, I've never heard of this before either. 
It does sound like a very interesting concept, however.

answers.text:
Caleb,
thanks for the response and the concept is picking up, we have found that the City of Auburn, Alabama and Auburn University have successfuly enjoyed this concept  for over 16 years.  Also, Kutztown University, Kutztown, PA, actually has two non-voting students on the council and they are also required to participate on three of the six council committees.  Penn State recently implemented the concept and the momentum and interest is growing.  Let ITGA know if you move forward on this.  Thanks, Kim

answers.author: Laurie Moyer
answers.text:
The City of San Marcos, Texas has had a non-voting representative on the City Council for about 6 years.  We are a community of 50,000 and the home of Texas State University with an enrollment of over 32,000.  The student representative is member of the Association of Student Government and is elected to sit with the City Council by their peers.  Most student representatives serve for a full school year.  While the student usually does not actively participate in the City Council discussions, their position on the dias does enable them to engage on relevant topics with the Council.
